steps.text: A vector space is a set V equipped with an addition and a scalar multiplication that satisfy certain properties.
steps.explanation: The addition of two vectors and the multiplication of a vector by a scalar must again yield a vector in V. Imagine a box of arrows—when you combine two arrows or stretch an arrow, you still get an arrow from the box!

steps.text: The addition must be commutative and associative, and there must exist a neutral element (zero vector).
steps.explanation: These properties ensure that vector addition behaves like ordinary addition. It’s like building with blocks: the order in which you combine them doesn’t matter, and adding nothing leaves everything unchanged!

steps.text: Scalar multiplication must be distributive and compatible with addition.
steps.explanation: These properties ensure that scalar multiplication interacts naturally with addition. It’s like stretching a rubber band: stretching two combined bands is the same as stretching them individually and then combining them!

steps.text: An important example is ℝⁿ, the vector space of n-tuples of real numbers.
steps.explanation: ℝⁿ is the standard vector space where vectors are represented as n-tuples of real numbers. In ℝ², we can think of it as points in a plane; in ℝ³, as points in space. Each point has its own coordinates!

steps.text: Another example is the vector space of polynomials of degree ≤ n.
steps.explanation: Polynomials form a vector space because they can be added and multiplied by scalars. Imagine having different functions that you can treat like vectors—you can add them or stretch them!

steps.text: A subspace is a subset of a vector space that is itself a vector space.
steps.formula: U \subseteq V \text{ is a subspace} \Leftrightarrow \begin{cases} \vec{0} \in U \\ \vec{u} + \vec{v} \in U \\ \alpha\vec{u} \in U \end{cases}
steps.explanation: A subspace must contain the zero vector and be closed under addition and scalar multiplication. It’s like a smaller space within a larger one—everything you do inside stays inside!

steps.text: The span of a set of vectors is the smallest subspace containing those vectors.
steps.explanation: The span contains all possible linear combinations of the given vectors. It’s like a net spanned by the vectors—every point in the net can be reached by combining the base vectors!

steps.text: A basis of a vector space is a linearly independent set of vectors that spans the entire space.
steps.formula: B = \{\vec{b}_1, ..., \vec{b}_n\} \text{ is a basis} \Leftrightarrow \begin{cases} B \text{ linearly independent} \\ \text{span}(B) = V \end{cases}
steps.explanation: A basis is like a coordinate system—every vector can be uniquely expressed as a linear combination of basis vectors. It’s like a construction kit from which you can build any vector!

steps.text: The dimension of a vector space is the number of vectors in a basis.
steps.explanation: The dimension gives us the number of independent directions in the vector space. In ℝ², we have two dimensions (x and y); in ℝ³, three (x, y, and z). It’s like the number of axes in our coordinate system!

steps.text: A scalar product is a function that assigns a real number to two vectors.
steps.explanation: The scalar product measures the similarity of two vectors. It’s like a measure of how aligned their directions are—when vectors are parallel, the scalar product is maximal!

steps.text: The norm of a vector is its length, defined via the scalar product.
steps.explanation: The norm gives us the length of a vector. In ℝ², it’s the distance from the origin to the point. It’s like a measuring tape for distances!

steps.text: Two vectors are orthogonal if their scalar product is zero.
steps.explanation: Orthogonal vectors are perpendicular to each other. In ℝ², the x- and y-axes are orthogonal. It’s like two roads meeting at a right angle!

steps.text: An orthonormal basis is a basis of pairwise orthogonal vectors of length 1.
steps.explanation: An orthonormal basis is particularly convenient because the vectors are perpendicular and have length 1. It’s like a perfect coordinate system where all axes are equally long!

steps.text: The vector space of continuous functions on an interval is an important example.
steps.explanation: Continuous functions form a vector space because they can be added and multiplied by scalars. It’s like a space full of curves that you can combine freely!

steps.text: The vector space of matrices is another important example.
steps.formula: M_{m,n} = \{A \mid A \text{ is an } m \times n \text{ matrix}\}
steps.explanation: Matrices form a vector space because they can be added and multiplied by scalars. It’s like a space full of tables that you can combine freely!

steps.text: The direct sum of two vector spaces is a new vector space.
steps.formula: V \oplus W = \{(v,w) \mid v \in V, w \in W\}
steps.explanation: The direct sum combines two vector spaces into a larger one. It’s like placing two spaces side by side—each vector consists of one part from each space!

steps.text: The quotient vector space arises by identifying vectors.
steps.explanation: The quotient vector space arises when we consider vectors differing only by a vector in U as equivalent. It’s like a space where certain differences are ignored!

steps.text: A vector space can also be defined over a finite field.
steps.explanation: Vector spaces over finite fields are important in coding theory. It’s like a space where we work with only a finite number of numbers!

steps.text: The dimension of a subspace cannot exceed that of the ambient space.
steps.explanation: A subspace cannot have more independent directions than the surrounding space. It’s like a room within a room—it cannot be larger than the outer space!

steps.text: The sum of two subspaces is again a subspace.
steps.formula: U + W = \{u + w \mid u \in U, w \in W\}
steps.explanation: The sum contains all possible sums of vectors from U and W. It’s like combining two spaces—every point can be expressed as a sum of points from both spaces!

steps.text: The intersection of two subspaces is again a subspace.
steps.formula: U \cap W = \{v \mid v \in U \text{ and } v \in W\}
steps.explanation: The intersection contains all vectors that lie in both subspaces. It’s like the common region of two overlapping spaces!

steps.text: The dimension of the sum of two subspaces satisfies the dimension formula.
steps.explanation: This formula relates the dimensions of the sum, intersection, and individual subspaces. It’s like a puzzle: the pieces must fit together!

steps.text: A vector space can also be defined as a module over a ring.
steps.formula: M \text{ is an } R\text{-module} \Leftrightarrow \begin{cases} M \text{ is an abelian group} \\ r \cdot m \in M \end{cases}
steps.explanation: Modules generalize vector spaces by allowing scalars from a ring instead of a field. It’s like a vector space where we can work with more types of numbers!

steps.text: Tensor products of vector spaces are important in multilinear algebra.
steps.formula: V \otimes W = \{\sum v_i \otimes w_i \mid v_i \in V, w_i \in W\}
steps.explanation: The tensor product combines vector spaces into a larger space. It’s like a product space where we can multiply vectors from different spaces!

steps.text: Finally, let’s look at how vector spaces are used in quantum mechanics.
steps.explanation: In quantum mechanics, states are represented as vectors in a complex vector space. It’s like a space full of possibilities, where each vector describes a possible state of the system!
